Chemistry
6. Chemistry

Kant draws a distinction between ‘proper’ and
‘rational’ science. The former denotes any discipline that
is strongly mathematized and relies on ‘apodictic’ laws,
supported by conclusive evidence; Newton’s gravitation theory is
the epitome of that. The latter indicates a body of propositions that
is systematic, viz. explanatorily integrated, and includes laws. Kant
counted chemistry as a poster child for it. He lived through a
watershed change in that discipline—from Georg Stahl’s
phlogiston theory to Lavoisier’s renovation of chemistry, its
core processes, and taxonomy of stuffs.

In Metaphysical Foundations, Kant argued that, in a
‘proper’ science, its basic concepts correlate with
mathematical notions, and the warrant for that correlation comes from
metaphysics, e.g. via a picture of the essence of matter. Thereby,
metaphysics supplies principles for the construction’ of the
domain-specific concepts of that science. But, he continued, no such
metaphysical warrant is available for correlating basic
chemical concepts with mathematics; when such correlations
occur, they are known a posteriori. (He was aware, of course, that
chemical practice in his time had discovered quantitative facts, e.g.
about the ratios of reagents in a specific reaction.) Thus, he
concluded, not only is chemistry not a proper science, but it is not
likely to become one ever (4:471).

Still, he counted it as a ‘rational’ science: he thought
chemistry owes its systematic order to ideas of reason. Specifically,
to certain domain-specific artificial concepts introduced for the sake
of descriptive and explanatory unification of many local regularities
established empirically. For instance, that all solid metals then
known ‘calcinate,’ i.e. form heavier compounds when heated
in air; and can be obtained from these compounds, under the right
laboratory conditions.

After 1790, Kant apparently moved to endorse Lavoisier’s new
taxonomy of chemical substances, and also his picture of the
‘caloric,’ or ‘ether’—a species of
‘imponderable fluid’ endowed with causal properties
relevant to, among others, heat exchanges, ‘combustion’
(oxidoreduction) and phase transitions. And yet, as recent research
has established, even in the post-Critical years Kant held fast to his
above requirements for a science to count as proper. In light of that,
late-Enlightenment chemistry—Lavoisier’s great
transformation and Kant’s ‘ether deduction’
notwithstanding—still counted for him as a rational, but
improper, science.

Interest in Kant’s philosophy of chemistry has surged in the
last decade. McNulty (2014, 2015, 2016) is an especially helpful and
clear series of studies of Kant’s engagement with that
rapidly-changing science. Blomme (2023) contributes to the question of
what chemistry was, for Kant. Older discussions of his views on the
topic are Carrier (1990, 2001) and Friedman (1992).
